text: uh
hi everyone anthony reid tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
james blake album friends that break
your heart this is the newest
full-length lp from singer songwriter
and producer mr james blake which comes
a few short years after the release of
his last record assume form and a decade
after the release of his debut
full-length album yeah we're now a
decade deep into the james blake
discography and it's been an interesting
ride so far and even with five full
lengths to his name now i still feel
like i never really know what to expect
will it be a sobering cover or a heady
electronic piece or an angelic piano
ballad or some kind of experimental beat
with a guest wrapper on it or maybe even
something that mashes all of those
elements together with james there's
truly no guessing which is why i was
surprised to hear on his latest lp that
he's more or less stylistically hanging
in the same place he was on his last
project you know in terms of the mix of
genres and styles coming together though
i'm noticing fewer jarring changes
across the track list more of a focus on
the ballads and the
features that are here seem a bit more
sensible or fitting to james's style
there are even some interesting
co-writer credits on the lp2 metro
boomin and james team up once again on
the song foot forward long time partner
jamila jamil has a few writer credits on
this lp hitmaker ali tamposi takes part
in a track as does joji on the song life
is not the same along with frequent lil
nasdaq's collaborators take a day trip
classical composer nico muley as well on
the closer so like with assume form a
lot of interesting names in the mix and
if you've heard that record much of what
james is doing here stylistically should
be familiar to you but don't take this
record as assume form part two because
this project does bring a significant
emotional shift to the table the themes
overall on assume form may have been a
bit scattered but the most consistent
one was easily love there was this
intoxicating feeling of infatuation
permeating many of the songs there but
now a majority of the songs on this
record see james blake
dejected abandoned insecure
absolutely wrecked there are even some
pretty deep themes of change and
transition expressed on
the opener as james sings about holding
on but wanting to let go of this feeling
or this person something that's haunting
him deep within his past from the lyrics
it's pretty clear this thing is a great
source of uh anguish and pain for him
and he speaks of feeling like he's lost
it because he's he's still thinking
about it to this day the instrumentals
interesting but still trademark james
blake all the way with its fusion of
electronics and very regal dramatic
patient balancing gentle hypnotic and
panned arpeggios eventually giving way
to super lush string sections james's
voice over all of it sounding amazing
still skilled expressive and raw and
bringing so much impact to his lyricism
this is also the case for the song life
is not the same which could very much be
coming from the same place narratively
because there are some overlapping
themes of betrayal a connection or
relationship falling apart and james
feeling left out to dry after putting so
much effort into it the pitched vocal
harmonies on the chorus are absolutely
haunting as are these breaks of why did
you go the hypnotic gentle b and distant
pianos make for a great combo on this
instrumental too then the track coming
back with sizzle was one that i was
looking forward to because i wondered
how james and her vocal chemistry would
work out here and overall it's fine
she's kind of segmented into her own
section as a feature and i like her
contribution and i think james's lyrics
are certainly on point here as he sings
about coming back with his tail between
his legs after having said something he
regrets and feeling like there's a mile
between his heart and his head but at
the same time i feel like the very
primped and straightforward chords and
piano loops stale out pretty fast the
somewhat poppy beat transition in the
midst of the track feels kind of out of
place within the scope of the rest of
the record too but the following funeral
is yet another devastating ballad with
not much more going for it other than
james's voice and electric piano and
even that in this moment feels like a
lot especially as he sings of knowing
this feeling too well being alive at his
own funeral uh going don't give up on me
continuing these feelings of atonement
and begging for forgiveness and given
the narratives of the record so far it's
interesting to think of whether or not
these feelings are being expressed
genuinely or in these moments of
weakness that james is singing about
where he finds himself bending over
backwards for a person or a connection
with basically nothing to show for it
frozen is an interesting detour of sorts
as the narrative kind of veers into
these very deep and dense rap verses
from jid and suave the flows and
lyricism on this track are great
especially suave who i think ran away
with the track with a super surreal
narrative and all these references back
to jib surrounding all of that you have
this very creative treatment of
some of the vocals be they james or be
they jids
some weird wishing noises and sound
effects thrown in here and there plucky
lead melodies a kind of heavy beat too
structurally the track features all
these strange linear transitions it may
be kind of a one-off stylistically in
the overall track list but this thing is
amazing just by virtue of being so well
executed and sounding like james is on
the verge of inventing a new genre i
will say though i'm so blessed your mind
does attempt a similar blend of chipmunk
vocals baladry and beets but i think the
cycling vocal samples on this track
mostly come off as goofy and a little at
odds with the grand and atmospheric
vocals and pianos growing in the
background all the dry perks and
atmospheric strings seem a bit at odds
too plus there's that kind of cluttered
and hideous bridge this is easily my
least favorite track on the lp then foot
forward was another moment where james
seemed locked into this kind of
uninspired and flat beat the piano loops
and perks especially on the front end
run really thin some of the lyrics on
this track come off a bit repetitive too
on top of that structurally it's not the
most robust on the album as it ends
kind of out of nowhere whole thing seems
like a motif or a rough idea or an
interlude parading itself as a song so
these tracks unfortunately add up to a
bit of a mid-point for the project
thankfully though the ending of this
record is really strong and sees james
diving back into that electronically
enhanced raw emotionally potent baladry
that dominated the first leg of the lp
the vocal chemistry between james blake
and monica martin on show me is great
especially on that enveloping bridge in
the second half that is so lush and
pillowy i want to die in it then say
what you will is really one of james
most revealing and diuristic songs ever
as he reflects on his fame and how that
famousness i guess
has only gone so far singing about being
okay essentially with uh living the life
or the time span of a meteor shower
which i get it i guess james blake is
not at that eminem level of fame and
influence but even that isn't guaranteed
relevancy forever i mean come on dude
you collab with beyonce give yourself a
damn break he delivers even more
devastating lyrics deeper into the track
about accepting his place without being
sour and
not making those psychopaths proud but
at least being able to see the faces of
the smaller crowds which again i think
he is beating himself up a bit too much
on this one but man the intensity with
which he feels these feelings on this
track is incredible he just like cries
all of this out like an injured animal
here there's a serene sweetness to the
track lost angel knights that i enjoy a
lot it feels like a lullaby in the midst
of again this very devastating album
some really clever lyrics too i love
this turn of phrase about him being in
his own way but in his own way he kept
you going for us whatever james is
holding on to with this record it does
seem to come to a point of closure at
least a little bit here but then we're
just thrown right back into the
emotional throws of depression with the
title track which uh pretty much you
know explains uh the feelings that have
inspired the title and the narrative of
this record and my god it hurts
it burns who hurt you james who heard
you because as he sings here he had
loves he's had loves but in the end it
was friends that broke his heart it's
messed up plus the fact that it's a very
well arranged acoustic ballad made for a
nice change of pace too then i'm
insecure leaves things off on an even
sadder cliffhanger in a way as he
sings very directly about his insecurity
and how it impacts his ability to
uh love and exist and just be live up to
the expectations and functions he would
have for any other person and the
sparkling electronics and vocal harmony
layers on this one are almost religious
the whole track feels like just again a
spiritual experience like an emotional
epiphany maybe with the realization
about insecurity he's making on this
track or the confrontation he's having
with his insecurity on this track he can
finally move past it and again i i do
think at least in part a major theme of
this record is you know moving past the
emotional traumas that have been kind of
dogging you for a long time look i'll
say overall with this record there are a
few rough patches yes that much is true
but i still think this is james's best
record since his debut it is well sung
and performed creatively produced some
of his best lyrics ever more thematic
focus than his last project plus i feel
the various genres that have inspired
him over the years coming together on
this one in a way that is a bit more
uniform and uniquely james blake feeling
a light eight on this lp tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and
please don't cry hit the bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video you can check out hit that up or
the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano james blake forever
